outline.text: Rotate, move, delete, extract, or renumber
pages in a PDF
Rotate pages in a PDF
You can rotate all or select pages in a document. Rotation is based on 90-degree increments.
Page Thumbnails You can rotate pages using the rotate tools in the pane or
Rotate the option.
All tools Organize pages. 1. Open the PDF in Acrobat, choose >
2. From the left pane, specify the page range on which you want to apply the rotation.
PAGES SELECTED Select the drop-down menu under , then select the appropriate
option. Alternatively, you can enter the page number you want to operate on.
3. After specifying the page range, for Direction, select either Rotate page left for
counterclockwise 90° rotation or Rotate page right° for clockwise 90° rotation .
4. You can also apply the page rotation on a specific page by selecting the buttons in the
right pane.
Note: To temporarily change your view of the page, from the hamburger menu (Windows)
View View Rotate view Rotate view right Rotate view or the menu (macOS), choose > > or
left . The original page orientation is restored the next time you open the PDF.
Extract pages from a PDF
Extraction is reusing selected pages of one PDF in a different PDF. Extracted pages include the
content and the form fields, comments, and links of the original document.
You can leave the extracted pages in the original document or remove them during
extraction.
Note: Any bookmarks or article threadings associated with pages aren't extracted.
All Tools Organize pages. 1. Open the PDF in Acrobat. From the upper left, select >
2. Specify the page range or the pages you want to extract. Select the drop-down menu
PAGES SELECTED under , then select the appropriate option. Alternatively, you can
enter the page number you want to operate on.
Extract pages PAGE OPTIONS 3. Select under .
Extract 4. In the dialog, select one or more of the following before you select :
Delete To remove the extracted pages from the original document, select •
pages after extracting .
Extract pages as To create a single-page PDF for each extracted page, select •
separate files .
To keep the original pages intact and create a single PDF for the extracted •
pages, deselect both options.
The extracted pages are placed in a new document.
Note: The creator of a PDF document can set the security to prevent the extraction of pages.
Document properties To view the security settings for a document, choose from the
File Security hamburger menu (Windows) or menu in macOS and then select the tab in
the dialog.
Extract random pages from a PDF
You can also select and extract discontinuous pages from the page thumbnails in the right
navigation pane of Acrobat.
2. Specify the pages which you want to extract separated with a comma. For example, if
you want to extract pages 3 and 5, enter 3, 5 in the pages field under PAGES
SELECTED.
Extract pages PAGE OPTIONS Select the under .
Extract 3. In the dialog, select one or more of the following before you select :
Split PDFs into multiple documents
You can split one or more PDFs into multiple smaller PDFs. When splitting a PDF, you can
specify the split by the maximum number of pages, maximum file size, or top-level
bookmarks.
PAGE OPTIONS Split. 2. In the left pane, under , select A command dialog appears for
the Split operation.
Split By 3. In the list, select the criteria for dividing the document:
Number of pages
Specify the maximum number of pages for each document in the split.
File Size
Specify the maximum file size for each document in the split.
Top-level Bookmarks
If the document includes bookmarks, it creates one document for every top-level
bookmark.
Output 4. To specify a target folder for the split files and filename preferences, select
Options OK . Specify the options as needed, and then select .
Split 5. Select .
Split multiple PDFs
Split by 3. In the list, select the criteria for dividing the document:
Split multiple files Add Files Add Files, Add Folders 5. Select . Select , and choose ,
Add Open Files OK Split or . Select the files or folder, and then select . Select .
Move or copy pages in a PDF
To copy or move pages within a document, use the page thumbnails in the right navigation
pane or the document area. You can also transfer pages between documents using these
thumbnails. In the Organize Pages view, drag and drop thumbnails to rearrange pages, or
select a thumbnail and copy it as needed.
Move or copy a page
All tools Organize pages 1. Open the PDF in Acrobat, and select > . The page thumbnails
are displayed in the Document area.
2. Select one or more page thumbnails.
3. Do one of the following:
To move a page, drag the corresponding page thumbnail to the new location. •
A bar will appear to show the new position of the page thumbnail. The pages
will be renumbered.
To cut or copy a page, select the page, and then select the ellipsis icon in the •
Cut Copy context menu bar displayed next to it. Select or from the context
menu. Select between the page thumbnails where you want to paste the page.
A blue horizontal marker shows the selected location where you want to paste.
Paste Select from the context menu. You can paste the pages in another PDF as
well.
Note: You can also move or copy pages by selecting the Page Thumbnails button from
the right pane.
Copy a page between two PDFs
1. Open both PDFs and display them alongside each other.
Window To display the PDFs side by side, select from the hamburger
Window Tile Vertically menu (Windows) or the menu (macOS). Then select > .
All tools Organize pages 2. Select > . The page thumbnails are displayed in the
Document area.
3. Select the page thumbnail of the page you want to cut or copy. To select multiple
pages, press Ctrl (Windows) or command (macOS) and then select the pages. From
Copy the page thumbnail context menu, select .
4. In the page thumbnails of the target PDF, select between the page thumbnails where
you want to insert the page. A blue horizontal marker indicates the location where you
Paste want to paste. Right-select and choose .
The page is copied into the document, and the pages are renumbered. You can paste
the pages in another PDF as well. Alternatively, you can also drag the page thumbnail
Page Thumbnails into the panel of the target PDF.
Delete or replace pages in a PDF
You can replace an entire PDF page with another PDF page. Only the text and images on the
original page are replaced. Any interactive elements associated with the original page, such as
links and bookmarks, aren't affected. Likewise, bookmarks and links that may have been
previously associated with the replacement page don't carry over. Comments, however, are
carried over and are combined with any existing comments in the document.
Reduce File Size After you delete or replace pages, it’s a good idea to use the command to
rename and save the restructured document to the smallest possible file size.
Delete multiple pages in a PDF
Note: Delete You can't undo the command.
All tools Organize pages 1. Select > . The page thumbnails are displayed in the
2. Specify the page thumbnail of the pages you want to delete and separate them with a
comma. For example, if you want to delete pages 3 and 5, enter 3, 5 in the pages field
PAGES SELECTED under .  You can also choose from the options given in the drop-
down menu.
Delete pages OK 3. In the left pane, select , and the select to confirm.
You can't delete all pages; at least one page must remain in the document.
Note: Use Logical Page Numbers Page Display If you select in the panel of
Preferences the dialog box, you can enter a page number in parentheses to delete the
corresponding page. For example, if the first page in the document is numbered i, you can
enter (1) in the Enter Page Range list, and the page is deleted.
Delete a page in a PDF
2. Select a page thumbnail of the page you want to delete. Then, select Delete
pages from the contextual toolbar that appears next to the selected page
thumbnail.
Replace pages in a PDF
1. Open the PDF that contains the pages you want to replace.
Replace 3. In the left tools pane, select . The file explorer window appears.
4. Select the document containing the replacement pages.
Replace Pages Original 5. In the dialog box, under , enter the pages to be replaced in the
original document.
Replace Pages Replacement 6. In the dialog box, under , enter the first page of the
replacement page range. The last page is calculated based on the number of pages to
be replaced in the original document.
OK 7. Select .
Replace pages between multiple PDFs
1. Open the PDF that contains the pages you want to replace, and then open the PDF
that contains the replacement pages.
All tools Organize pages 2. Select > for both PDFs. The page thumbnails are displayed in
the Document area.
3. In the PDF containing the replacement pages, select a page or group of pages you
Ctrl want as replacements. For Windows, press and then select the pages; for MacOS,
Command press and then select the pages.
Ctrl command 4. Press (Windows) or (macOS) and then drag the selected page
thumbnails in the document area of the target document where thumbnails are
displayed. Release the mouse button when the pointer is directly over the page
number box of the page thumbnail you want to replace. The corresponding pages are
highlighted.
The pages you selected in the first document replace an equal number of pages in the
second document. It starts at the page number that you selected to drop the new
pages.
Renumber pages in a PDF
The page numbers on the document pages don't always match the page numbers that appear
Page Navigation below the page thumbnails and in the right toolbar. Pages are numbered
with integers, starting with page 1 for the first page of the document. Because some PDFs may
contain front matter, such as a copyright page and table of contents, their body pages may
Page Navigation not follow the numbering shown in the right toolbar.
You can specify various numbering styles for a group of pages, for example, 1, 2, 3, or i, ii, iii, or
a, b, c. You can also customize the numbering system by adding a prefix. For example, pages
in Chapter 1 can be 1-1, 1-2, 1-3, and so on. Chapter 2 can have pages numbered as 2-1, 2-2, 2-3,
and so on.
Note: Number Pages Using the command affects only the page thumbnails on
Pages the panel. You can physically add new page numbers to a PDF using the headers and
footers feature.
All tools Organize pages > Page labels. 1. Select from the global bar. Then select
Selected Page Thumbnails 2. Specify a page range. ( implies pages selected in the panel.)
OK 3. Select one of the following, and then select :
Begin New Section : Starts a new numbering sequence. Choose a style from the pop-up
Prefix menu, and enter a starting page number for the section. Specify a , if desired.
Extend Numbering Used In Preceding Section To Selected Pages : Continues the numbering
sequence from previous pages without interruption.
Edit Scanned PDFs
Editing a scanned PDF can be complicated if it includes low-quality text or images, non-
editable text, line breaks, or complex formatting. Other inhibiting factors include compatibility
issues, security restrictions, and large file sizes, which are more prevalent in PDFs created from
scanned images.
To streamline the process, consider the following best practices and guidelines before editing
a scanned document:
Check the accuracy of optical character recognition (OCR) output . When you open a
scanned document, Acrobat automatically runs OCR in the background to make the
document editable. Before editing, review the document to ensure that the content is
Scan & OCR Recognize accurate and complete. If necessary, rescan the document using the >
Text tool to improve the output.
Enhance image quality Enhance . If the scanned PDF contains low-quality images, use the
scanned file Enhance camera image or feature to improve the quality of images before
attempting to edit the document. For more information, see Scan documents to PDF .
Use the correct font and formatting . When editing the document, ensure that the font and
formatting of the edited text match the original document as closely as possible. If you don't
have the desired fonts on your computer, see Add fonts to your computer .
Remove security restrictions . If the scanned PDF has security restrictions that prevent editing,
remove these restrictions before attempting to edit the document. To know how to remove
security from a PDF, see Unlock a PDF .
Avoid editing complex elements . If the scanned PDF contains tables, graphs, or images,
avoid unnecessary edits that could alter the layout or formatting of these elements.
Check for compatibility issues . Ensure that the version of Adobe Acrobat you're using is
compatible with the scanned PDF. If you encounter compatibility issues, try updating Adobe
Acrobat. For more information, see System requirements .
Save a backup copy . Always save a backup copy of the original scanned PDF before making
any edits. Revert to the original document if any issues arise during the editing process.
Recognize text on scanned PDF
You can use the Scan & OCR tool to recognize text, change OCR language, and make all
pages editable in one go. To do so:
Get 1. Open the scanned file, and then from the top banner that appears, select
started .
It opens the Scan & OCR tool options in the left panel
In this file 2. From the left panel, under Recognize text, select .
3. In the dialog that opens, select the pages that you want to apply text
recognition for and the language.
Recognize text 4. Select .
Edit a scanned document
1. Open the scanned PDF file in Acrobat.
Edit 2. From the global bar in the upper left, select .
3. Select the text element that you want to edit and start typing. The new text matches
the original font in your scanned PDF.
4. From the upper-left corner, select the hamburger menu (Windows) or File
Save as (macOS)> and enter a new name for your document.
Initially, the language is set to the default locale, and the other options are disabled. Any
changes to these settings are persisted and are applied when you edit the document.
Enhance scanned file or camera images for
clear PDFs
Enhance camera You can capture document photos with your smartphone and use the
image feature to create polished, clear, and compact PDFs without needing a standard
scanner. This feature addresses common issues in mobile-captured images, such as incorrect
perspectives, areas beyond boundaries, shadows, and inconsistent lighting. While it may not
eliminate all problems, it significantly improves the overall quality of your resulting PDF.
Enhance camera image
1. Open the photograph or image of the document in Acrobat.
All tools Scan & OCR 2. From the menu, select .
Enhance camera image 3. From the left panel, select and then from the dialog that
Enhance opens, select .
4. The image is enhanced and a PDF of the image is shown.
5. (Optional) To further adjust the default enhancement level, drag the Adjust
enhancement level slider in the secondary toolbar.
